DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze on Tuesday symbolically ended 40 years of East-West hostility and suspicion by paying a visit to NATO headquarters. He said the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact should stay in place to help ensure stability at a time of tumultuous change on the European continent. Shevardnadze later went before the European Parliament, the legislative arm of the European Community, and strongly cautioned against quick efforts to unite the two Germanys. Leaders of the 12-nation trading bloc recently gave their strong backing to eventual reunification. The Soviet official noted East Germany was an ally in the Warsaw Pact and said: ``It is necessary to proceed on the basis of the postwar realities, namely, the existence of two sovereign German states. ... A retreat from that is fraught with destabilization in Europe.'' Later, Shevardnadze flew to London, where he got a strong endorsement from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for keeping NATO and the Warsaw Pact in place. Neither Mrs. Thatcher and Shevardnadze would give details of their 2-hour discussion. But Shevardnadze said that ``on a number of very important world issues, both global issues and regional issues, we have a very good measure of agreement.'' Shevardnadze's unprecedented visit to NATO headquarters on the outskirts of Brussels was a dramatic sign of the reduced military tensions between Western nations and their potential adversaries in the East bloc. NATO was formed in 1949 to guard against the security threat posed by the Soviet Union. After meeting with NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner, Shevardnadze joked that his visit had been likened to traveling to a volcano's crater. But he said he found ``a very friendly atmosphere. So this was not a terrible thing.'' Shevardnadze, who also met the ambassadors of the 16 NATO nations, stressed the need for continuing the two alliances. ``We do believe the Warsaw Treaty and NATO at this crucial stage in European development ... are able to play a very important stabilizing role,'' he told reporters. Woerner, a former German defense minister, said Shevardnadze mentioned in their private talks ``the very essential role of the Americans here in Europe.'' The officials said they agreed an East-West accord on slashing conventional, or non-nuclear, weapons in Europe could be wrapped up next year. They said the United States and the Soviet Union also should reach agreement in 1990 on a new treaty cutting long-range nuclear weapons. Woerner said Shevardnadze suggested formal contacts be set up between the two military alliances. But the NATO chief said he reminded Shevardnadze that NATO, unlike the Warsaw Pact, was a voluntary association of democratically elected governments. William H. Taft IV, the American ambassador to NATO, said the Warsaw Pact ``needs to do some more changing before it's a proper partner in dialogue with NATO.'' No surprises were reported. ``It was an important event (but) the importance was really a symbolic one rather than substantive,'' said Gordon Smith, Canada's envoy to NATO. Added Taft, ``It was more of a get-acquainted session.'' In his speech to the European Parliament, Shevardnadze welcomed U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III's recent call for NATO to adopt a more political role in an era of reduced tensions. He said the Warsaw Pact also must change with ``political aspects prevailing over its military substance.'' But the focus of his remarks was on the subject of German unity, which has gained increasing attention with the opening of borders between the two countries. Shevardnadze the question of borders in Europe was settled permanently but the Germanys retained the right to self-determination. He said there should be ``due regard for the special position of the two German states and their responsibility to assure all nations of Europe and the world that a threat of war will never again come from the German soil.'' He said a number of questions remained unanswered. ``Where are the ... guarantees that German unity would not eventually create a threat to the national security of other states and to peace in Europe,'' he asked. He wondered where a united Germany would fit into military-political structures. ``One cannot seriously expect the status of (East Germany) to change radically while the status of (West Germany) would remain the same,'' he said. ``Surely the peoples of the Soviet Union are entitled to know what any changes in Central Europe would mean for their future and their security,'' he said. ``We paid the price of 20 million lives for the existing European stability.'' ``Furthermore, can the German people themselves forget the national tragedy brought onto them by Hitlerism,'' he said.
